Ideally, I think we just need to add a range query method to `ElasticSearchClient`, and provide a generator for index names including all ranges. The codes should be easy to maintain.

It is better to use `getTraceId` after the Spring Controller.

@tmacjx
I used flask to test in the environment of gunicorn, it can run normally.

```
import requests

from skywalking import config, agent


config.service_name = 'consumer'
config.logging_level = 'DEBUG'
config.flask_collect_http_params = True
agent.start()

from flask import Flask, jsonify

app = Flask(__name__)

@app.route("/users", methods=["POST", "GET"])
def application():
    requests.post("http://github.com")

    return jsonify({"test": "hello world"})
```

command：`gunicorn -w 4 test_gunicorn:app` 

when i use `uwsgi --http 127.0.0.1:8000 --buffer-size=65536 --processes=4 --module test_gunicorn:app `  still work well，but segment report slowed。
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1763449/89791766-4e90bc00-db56-11ea-9e58-b6e945e28a98.png)

> Ideally, I think we just need to add a range query method to `ElasticSearchClient`, and provide a generator for index names including all ranges. The codes should be easy to maintain.

there is a problem. day steps info is not contains in client library.so cannot compute index name in client library module
that is why i write the codes in storage module

> there is a problem. day steps info is not contains in client library.so cannot compute index name in client library module
that is why i write the codes in storage module

This calculation should be a part of TimeSeriesUtils, that is right.

there is 2 ways :
1. build a client wrapper for es search. 
2. TimeSeriesUtils build index names. pass the indices to es client library module.

in my option, first way is easy to maintain. in second way ,maybe forgot it at  some time.
Of course the first can be more elegant

> build a client wrapper for es search.

Wrapper is fine, my point is, the current codes are mixing the normal(99%) search and the range query(for trace only). I want to separate them, which is easier to read and make the reviewer easier for more queries in the future.

I tested Django==3.1, apache-skywalking==0.2.0.  it worked well @shuguang-dong
```
import sys
import time

from skywalking import agent, config

from django.conf import settings
from django.conf.urls import url
from django.http import JsonResponse


config.service_name = "provider"
config.logging_level = "DEBUG"
agent.start()


settings.configure(
    DEBUG=True,
    ROOT_URLCONF=__name__,
    ALLOWED_HOSTS=['*'],
)


def index(request):
    time.sleep(0.5)
    return JsonResponse({"song": "Despacito", "artist": "Luis Fonsi"})


urlpatterns = (
    url("users", index),
)


if __name__ == "__main__":
    from django.core.management import execute_from_command_line

    execute_from_command_line(sys.argv)
```
cmd: python3 test_django.py runserver 0.0.0.0:9090

> TimeSeriesUtils build index names. pass the indices to es client library module.

Even for this, I don't think there is a forgotten thing, because if you just access one index, you can't get enough data. In SkyWalking, you either use the alias or the real index names.
You could make ES client accepting the current index name or a index name builder.

I think #5084 has fixed this.
DEADLINE_EXCEEDED means timeout in GRPC.

You should add `lastPingTimestamp` in the [ServiceInstance entity](https://github.com/apache/skywalking-query-protocol/blob/master/metadata.graphqls#L31). This is the time bucket in the backend time format.

You could query the service list first, then get all instance lists with this time bucket(in minute level).

Then across check with [OAP time info](https://github.com/apache/skywalking-query-protocol/blob/master/metadata.graphqls#L89), you could have the status(alive or not).

WDYT?
This requires very small change in the backend and a new page for this feature.
